data: Let  𝐴 be an  𝑚×𝑛 matrix and let  𝑏 be a vector in  ℝ𝑚. A least-squares solution of the matrix equation  𝐴𝑥=𝑏 is a vector  𝑥̂  in  ℝ𝑛 such that dist(𝑏,𝐴𝑥̂ )≤dist(𝑏,𝐴𝑥) for all other vectors  𝑥 in  ℝ𝑛.Col(𝐴) is the set of all vectors of the form 𝐴𝑥. Recall that  dist(𝑣,𝑤)=‖𝑣−𝑤‖ is the distance, Definition 6.1.2 in Section 6.1, between the vectors  𝑣 and  𝑤. The term “least squares” comes from the fact that  dist(𝑏,𝐴𝑥)=‖𝑏−𝐴𝑥̂ ‖ is the square root of the sum of the squares of the entries of the vector  𝑏−𝐴𝑥̂  . So a least-squares solution minimizes the sum of the squares of the differences between the entries of  𝐴𝑥̂  and  𝑏 . In other words, a least-squares solution solves the equation  𝐴𝑥=𝑏 as closely as possible, in the sense that the sum of the squares of the difference  𝑏−𝐴𝑥 is minimized.Hence, the closest vector, Note 6.3.1 in Section 6.3, of the form 𝐴𝑥 to 𝑏 is the orthogonal projection of 𝑏 onto Col(𝐴). This is denoted 𝑏Col(𝐴)
goal:
**Extracted Core Principle:**
The concept of the least-squares solution as the orthogonal projection of the vector \( b \) onto the column space of the matrix \( A \), illustrating how it minimizes the distance between \( b \) and the vectors formed by \( A \).

**Query:**
Create a visualization to explain the concept of the least-squares solution as the orthogonal projection of vector \( b \) onto the column space \( \text{Col}(A) \). This visualization should depict vector \( b \), the column space of matrix \( A \), and the vector \( A\hat{x} \) that represents the least-squares solution. Highlight the geometric relationship, showing the distances involved and how the least-squares solution minimizes the distance \( \text{dist}(b, A\hat{x}) \) compared to any other vector formed by \( A \).

The visualization should employ a diagram style to clearly illustrate the orthogonality between the vector \( b - A\hat{x} \) and the column space \( \text{Col}(A) \). This will aid students in understanding the spatial relationships and the critical role of orthogonal projection within the least-squares context. The visual representation should be labeled clearly, indicating vectors, distances, and mathematical relationships.

**Educational Objective:**
Students will develop an in-depth understanding of the least-squares solution by visually grasping how it minimizes the distance to the given vector \( b \) through orthogonal projection. By illustrating the geometrical significance of this concept, learners will comprehend the foundational principles of least squares in linear algebra and be able to articulate the importance of orthogonality in vector spaces.
code:
import numpy as np
import matplotlib.pyplot as plt

# Define vectors
A_hat_x = np.array([2, 3])  # Least-squares solution
b = np.array([3, 1])  # Given vector b

# Calculate the vector b - A_hat_x
b_minus_A_hat_x = b - A_hat_x

# Create figure and axis
fig, ax = plt.subplots(figsize=(8, 6))

# Set limits
ax.set_xlim(0, 4)
ax.set_ylim(0, 4)

# Draw the column space of A
ax.fill_between([0, 4], [0, 0], [0, 4], color='lightblue', alpha=0.5, label='Col(A)', zorder=1)

# Draw vector b
ax.quiver(0, 0, b[0], b[1], angles='xy', scale_units='xy', scale=1, color='orange', label='Vector b', zorder=2)

# Draw vector A_hat_x
ax.quiver(0, 0, A_hat_x[0], A_hat_x[1], angles='xy', scale_units='xy', scale=1, color='green', label='A\\hat{x}', zorder=3)

# Draw the projection
ax.quiver(b[0], b[1], -b_minus_A_hat_x[0], -b_minus_A_hat_x[1], angles='xy', scale_units='xy', scale=1,
           color='red', linestyle='--', label='b - A\\hat{x}', zorder=4)

# Annotations
ax.annotate('b', xy=(b[0], b[1]), xytext=(b[0] + 0.1, b[1] - 0.1), fontsize=12, color='orange')
ax.annotate('A\\hat{x}', xy=(A_hat_x[0], A_hat_x[1]), xytext=(A_hat_x[0] + 0.1, A_hat_x[1]), fontsize=12, color='green')
ax.annotate('b - A\\hat{x}', xy=(b[0] - b_minus_A_hat_x[0] / 2, b[1] - b_minus_A_hat_x[1] / 2), 
            xytext=(b[0] - b_minus_A_hat_x[0] / 2 - 0.5, b[1] - b_minus_A_hat_x[1] / 2 + 0.5), 
            fontsize=12, color='red')

# Add labels and title
plt.title('Least-Squares Solution as Orthogonal Projection', fontsize=14)
plt.xlabel('X-axis', fontsize=12)
plt.ylabel('Y-axis', fontsize=12)

# Add grid and legend
plt.grid()
plt.legend()

# Show the plot
plt.axis('equal')
